titleStmt.title: INTEROCEPTION AND MORAL INTUITION Interoceptive ability predicts moral intuition aligned with group consensus INTEROCEPTION AND MORAL INTUITION

analytic.title: INTEROCEPTION AND MORAL INTUITION Interoceptive ability predicts moral intuition aligned with group consensus INTEROCEPTION AND MORAL INTUITION

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Aligning one's decisions with the prevailing norms and expectations of those around us constitutes a fundamental facet of moral decision-making. When faced with conflicting moral values, one adaptive approach is to rely on intuition. While there has been theoretical speculation about the connection between moral decision-making and an individual's awareness of introspective interoceptive signals, it has not been empirically examined. This study examines this link in the context of decision-making in moral dilemma of university students. Our research demonstrates a correlation between an individual's moral intuition towards group consensus and their interoceptive abilities. Study 1 found that interoceptive awareness and the intrinsic functional connectivity of anterior insula are associated with individuals' moral intuition. Study 2

div.p: showed that interoceptive accuracy is associated with moral intuition toward the group consensus.
These findings provide empirical evidence of the link between interoceptive abilities and moral intuition towards group consensus.

div.head: Statement of Relevance
div.p: This study aims to investigate individuals' proclivity for moral decision-making by examining their alignment with group-level consensus and its connection to interoception. Our findings indicate a positive correlation between an individual's interoceptive awareness and accuracy and the degree to which their moral decisions align with group-wide judgments. Furthermore, this inclination to make moral decisions congruent with the collective consensus becomes apparent at the resting state connectivity level of the anterior insula-a region renowned for its involvement in interoceptive processing. These findings offer for a foundational understanding of how individuals develop internal models of societal expectations and employ them when navigating moral dilemmas.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: How do people navigate the complexities of moral decision-making when clear answers are elusive? Morality represents a set of principles endorsed by rational individuals under specific circumstances (Gert, 2004). Moral decisions are heavily influenced by societal and cultural norms and are driven by moral intuition to align with these norms and others' expectations (Haidt, 2001).

Recent theories propose that following this sense of moral duty reduces the metabolic costs of maintaining bodily homeostasis, potentially enhancing our chances of survival by efficiently regulating our physiological processes (Mayer, 2011;Theriault et al., 2021). In social contexts, individuals construct mental models of the world that incorporate information about how others perceive and interpret their surroundings. Acting as what others would generally expect of oneself, or following one's 'sense of should', contributes to the maintenance of a predictive social environment by reducing the predictive errors that others might encounter, and not prompting adjustments to their internal models (Constant et al., 2019;Theriault et al., 2021).

Given that moral preferences are heavily affected by culture (Awad et al., 2018), we propose that moral intuitions reflect internal models of what the majority in a society would expect in specific situations.

Interoception is central to the allostatic process of the brain (Sterling, 2012). It helps build and maintain elaborate models of the internal and external milieu (Barrett et al., 2004) crucial for maintaining bodily homeostasis (Pezzulo et al., 2015) and is recognized as a critical factor in social cognition and decision making (Damasio, 1996). Different dimensions of interoceptive abilities have been associated with individual differences in emotional perception and adaptive and efficient behaviors (Garfinkel et al., 2015). For example, individuals with higher interoceptive accuracy often report more intense emotional experiences when exposed to various emotion-inducing stimuli (Wiens et al., 2010), tend to make more advantageous decisions (Dunn et al., 2010;Werner et al., 2009), and exhibit heightened prosocial behavior (Nentjes et al., 2013).

Moral dilemmas involve options that prioritize different ethical values. While they lack clear right or wrong answers, some options are more likely to be accepted and expected by the majority within a social group (Greene et al., 2001;Koenigs et al., 2007). Conforming to these social expectations can enhance the predictability of one's social environment since others do not need to revise their existing expectations of the conformer's intentions or behavior. This conformity may be an efficient behavior that minimizes the metabolic demands on the body, reducing the need for extra effort to infer the expectations of others (Theriault et al., 2021). Such conformity may necessitate an intimate brain-body interaction, as supported by findings indicating that the neural circuitry involved in decision making influenced by social observation, such as medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and insula (D. Jung et al., 2018;D. Kim et al., 2023;Li et al., 2021;Yoon et al., 2021), overlaps with the regions implicated in interoceptive inference (Kleckner et al., 2017). Thus, we hypothesize that higher interoceptive sensitivity is associated with a greater inclination to align with prevailing moral norms, particularly in decisions concerning moral dilemmas. Such decisions may minimize the metabolic costs associated with bodily maintenance, as aligning with others' expectations increases the likelihood of preserving the current internal model of what others anticipate (Theriault et al., 2021).

Interoceptive accuracy is correlated with both task-related brain activity and resting state connectivity emanating from the insular cortex (Chong et al., 2017;Critchley et al., 2004;Seth, 2013), the hub of the interoceptive network (Craig, 2009). We hypothesized that the resting state anterior insular cortex functional connectivity would correlate with moral decision-making oriented toward group consensus. Specifically, we anticipated that the connectivity between the insular cortex and regions within the default mode network (DMN), such as mPFC or precuneus, would be pivotal in aligning an internal model with the moral consensus of the group, as the DMN is crucial in generating internal models of the world through multisensory predictions (Buckner, 2012;Kleckner et al., 2017).

In this study, we investigated the relationship between interoception and moral intuition oriented toward group consensus. Study 1 examined whether self-reported interoceptive sensitivity correlated with the inclination to make moral decisions that align more closely with group consensus. Participants read moral dilemma scenarios, making binary choices between deontological and utilitarian options. Subsequently, they responded to an online questionnaire assessing interoceptive awareness. We also investigated the neural signatures of moral intuition oriented towards group consensus in resting state fMRI data. Study 2 sought to validate the relationship between interoceptive sensitivity and moral intuition geared toward group consensus, using the heartbeat counting task to obtain objective measures of interoceptive accuracy.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Study was conducted as an exploratory behavioral pilot experiment to test our hypothesis that interoceptive sensitivity is related to the degree to which one's moral decisions match the group consensus. Participants, who were university students recruited through online communities of local universities in Seoul, were selected from a larger database where they initially participated in the data collection for another research project. Out of 109 participants recruited for the initial research project, 74 participants (mean age = 23.55, std = 2.30, 36 males) had agreed to participate in this study and therefore were provided with an online link to the moral dilemma task along with instruction on how to participate in the task. All participants performed the online moral dilemma task within a week after scanning. The same participants' resting-state functional MRI data were used to examine the neural signatures of moral decisions toward group consensus.

In study 2, we aimed to replicate the relationship between the moral decision-making tendency and interoceptive accuracy, using a more objective measure of interoceptive sensitivity. This study included 30 participants (mean age = 24.63, std = 2.34, 15 males) who were all university students recruited through online university communities in Seoul. The participants performed the moral dilemma task online through the same procedure as used for Study 1, and then visited the behavioral experiment laboratory located at Korea University to participate in the heartbeat counting task while ECG data were acquired. All participants provided informed consent, and the entire research protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Korea University.

div.head: Moral dilemma task
div.p: Forty-eight moral dilemma scenarios used in the online moral dilemma task were selected from those used in two previous studies (FeldmanHall et al., 2014;Greene et al., 2001). These were translated into Korean first and rated for difficulty in vocabulary and coherency of the sentences by 14 independent raters who were all native Korean university students recruited through an online university community. Each rater read the scenario and rated the difficulty of the text on a 5-point scale from 0 (not difficult at all) to 4 (very difficult). For the scenarios where the rating was above 3 points, the raters were asked which part of the scenario was difficult to understand and to provide an alternative sentence or words to make the scenario clearer to understand. The feedback from the raters was applied to modify and improve the translation of the scenarios used in Studies 1 and 2. The scenarios included 25 personal dilemmas, where participants had to decide whether to directly cause harm to another person for another moral cause, and 23 impersonal scenarios.

The participants were asked to read the scenario and make a binary choice on how they would act in the scenario as the protagonist. The utilitarian choices were coded as 1 and the deontological choices were coded as 0. Then they were asked to rate the difficulty of the decision they just made on a 5-point Likert scale where 1 was extremely easy and 5 was extremely difficult. The task was self-paced as each participant could have a different reading speed. In both Study 1 and 2, the task was implemented using jsPsych library (de Leeuw, 2015), and the data were collected through 'Cognition.run' server.

div.head: Group consensus moral decisions
div.p: The group consensus moral decision for each scenario was defined in both binary and continuous manners. First, the option that the majority of all the participants from the two studies (52 or more participants) chose was defined as the group consensus moral decision for a given scenario.

Second, as a continuous measure of group consensus moral decision, the ratio of participants who chose the utilitarian option for each scenario was calculated. For instance, in a trolley dilemma, if 51% of the participants chose to turn the switch to save five people sacrificing one person, then the utilitarian choice was considered to be the group consensus decision for the scenario (Fig. 1A). The scenarios were categorized into high and low group consensus scenarios based on the ratio of participants making the same decision. Scenarios where 25% to 75% of the participants made the utilitarian decision were categorized as low consensus scenarios, and those with lower than 25% or higher than 75% were categorized as high consensus scenarios.
We assessed the individual tendency of moral decisions toward group consensus in two ways.

First, the moral similarity to group measure was defined as the ratio of scenarios where each participant made the same binary decision as the group consensus moral decision. Second, the moral distance from the group measure was defined as the average Euclidean distance between the participant's binary choice and the group-level ratio of utilitarian choice across all the scenarios. The two measures of moral intuition towards group consensus were calculated separately for scenarios with low and high level of group consensus as well as for personal and impersonal scenarios.

The two measures of group consensus moral decisions, the ratio of utilitarian choices for each scenario, and the decision of the majority of the group, as well as the two measures of individual's moral intuition towards group consensus, were also assessed separately for Study 1 and Study 2.

div.head: Self-report questionnaires
div.p: All the participants completed the Korean Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (K-MAIA (Gim et al., 2016)), which is a 32-item Korean edition of MAIA (Mehling et al., 2012). This questionnaire comprises 5 sub-scales measuring awareness and attention to bodily sensations and the connection between body sensations and emotional states. All the participants in Study 2 completed the Korean version of Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (H. Kim & Han, 2016).

div.head: Heartbeat Counting Task
div.p: In Study 2, interoceptive accuracy (IAcc) was assessed by a heartbeat counting task (Schandry, 1981). Participants were seated in front of a monitor and were asked to concentrate on their internal body states and count their heartbeats starting from the onset of the start signal until the stop signal appeared on the screen. The start and the stop signals for counting heartbeats were visually shown on the monitor. The participants' actual heartbeats were recorded using an electrocardiogram acquisition system (Biopac, MP36). The electrodes were attached in the Lead 2 position. The task was conducted six times, each with different durations (25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50 sec). Participants were not informed of the length of the duration of the trial. The sequence of the trials was randomized once and fixed for all the participants. Participants were instructed to honestly report the number of heartbeats they felt, and not to touch their body (e.g., wrist) to feel the actual pressure of the pulses. For each participant, the individual IAcc was evaluated by the difference between the number of actual heartbeats and the reported heartbeats and calculated as below (Dunn et al., 2010;Pollatos & Schandry, 2008):

div.head: Statistical analysis of behavioral data
div.p: The behavioral data were analyzed using SPSS 25 software. One-sample T-tests were performed to test whether the moral similarity to group consensus was above chance level. In Study 1, bivariate linear relationships between interoceptive awareness and moral similarity to group consensus, and between interoceptive awareness and moral distance from group consensus were assessed by computing Pearson correlations. In Study 2, bivariate Pearson correlations between interoceptive accuracy and moral similarity to group consensus, and interoceptive accuracy and moral distance from group consensus were assessed by computing Pearson correlations. Also, partial correlations between interoceptive accuracy and moral similarity to group consensus, and between interoceptive accuracy and moral distance from group consensus, controlling for individuals' alexithymia level, were assessed to examine whether the ability to link visceral signals to conscious level of emotional experience is related to having moral intuition towards group consensus.

Mediation effect was also tested to assess the mediating role of the moral intuition towards group consensus in the effect of interoceptive accuracy on the subjectively reported empathy level. We ran the mediation analysis using bootstrapping approach using 5000 samples implemented simultaneously in a single regression step (Hallquist et al., 2013). Linear detrending was also applied.

div.head: Regions-of-interest selection
div.p: We aimed to investigate whether the intrinsic functional connectivity of regions related to interoceptive processing was related to individual differences in making moral decisions following the moral intuition for group consensus. Thus, our region of interest (ROI) was agranular anterior insular cortex (Critchley et al., 2004;Kleckner et al., 2017), which was defined from a high-resolution anatomic template that parcellates the brain into 246 subregions based on the region's connectivity patterns (Fan et al., 2016). We also tested whether the connectivity between agranular anterior insular cortex and brain regions included in the DMN, which are the precuneus, bilateral TPJ and MPFC, are also related to such moral decision making tendency. The four regions were defined from the default resting state parcellation provided in the CONN20b toolbox (Whitfield-Gabrieli & Nieto-Castanon, 2012).

div.head: Functional connectivity analysis
div.p: Whole-brain seed-to-voxel connectivity was conducted using the CONN20b toolbox (Whitfield-

Gabrieli & Nieto-Castanon, 2012). Individual correlation maps of each seed ROI were generated by calculating the correlation coefficients between the mean BOLD time series of the seed ROI with that of each voxel throughout the whole brain. These maps were used in the second-level analysis investigating the correlation between the seed-to-voxel connectivity and the individual tendency of moral decision towards group consensus after controlling for age and gender effects.

The results were first thresholded at uncorrected p < 0.001 to initially define clusters of interest from the original statistical parametric maps and corrected for multiple comparisons to a significance level of FDR-p < 0.05 at cluster level.

To assess the significance of the moral intuition towards group consensus on the connectivity between the anterior insula and 4 landmark anatomical regions of the DMN, we performed an ROI-level analysis using the REX toolbox (Duff et al., 2007). We extracted the effect size of moral distance from each of the 4 clusters of the DMN template, provided as default classic resing state networks in CONN, and conducted one-sample t-test.

div.head: Individuals' moral decisions resemble group consensus moral decision
div.p: Individual's moral similarity to group consensus was calculated as the percentage of individual's decisions that match the majority decision of the participants from both studies (i.e. Study 1 and

Study 2) for each scenario. The mean score of the moral similarity to group consensus was significantly above the chance level in both Study 1 (M = .790, SD = .054, t(73) = 46.165, p < .001) and Study 2 (M = .718, SD = .130, t(29) = 9.177, p < .001; Fig 1C). This moral similarity to group consensus was not related to the average percentage of utilitarian decisions (r(104) = .016, p = .870; Fig 1D). To examine whether the group consensus decisions are stable across different studies, the percentage of utilitarian choices for each scenario was calculated and the correlation of the ratios across Study 1 and Study 2 were assessed. This analysis demonstrated that the group consensus percentages of the two independent study samples were highly correlated (r(47) = .968, p < .001; Fig 1B). The percentage of participants making the utilitarian choice for each scenario was highly correlated across two studies, indicating that the group consensus moral decision for each scenario was consistent across two studies. (C) Participants made moral decisions that match the group consensus moral decision above chance level in both Study 1 and Study 2.

(D) Moral similarity to the group's consensus decision, defined as the percentage of decisions that match the group consensus moral decision, was not related to individuals' tendency of making utilitarian choices across participants in Study 1 and Study 2.

div.head: Subjective and objective measures of interoception are related to the individual tendency of making moral decisions toward group consensus
div.p: To test our a priori hypothesis, we assessed the relationship between subjective measures of individuals' interoceptive awareness and moral intuition towards group consensus, or the degree to which they make moral decisions in line with group consensus. The moral intuition toward group consensus was defined either as the percentage of scenarios that one's decisions match the group consensus decisions (i.e., moral similarity to the group) or as the mean Euclidean distance of the individual's choice from the percentage of utilitarian decision at the group level for each scenario (i.e., moral distance from the group). For an example of the latter, if 30 percent of the group chose the utilitarian option (coded as 1) in a scenario, and a participant chose the deontological option (coded as 0) for the scenario, then the Euclidean distance for that scenario would be √(0.3 − 0) 2 = 0.3 for this participant, and if another participant chose the utilitarian option, the distance for that scenario of this participant would be √(0.3 − 1) 2 = 0.7. This measure more accurately reflects the similarity of individual's decision to the group level moral consensus for scenarios with lower level of consensus, because scenarios with group level utilitarian percentage near 50% would change drastically when assessing similarity in a binary manner. These two measures of group consensus moral decision were highly negatively correlated in both Study 1 (r(74) = -.826, p < .001) and Study 2 (r(30) = -.829, p < .001),

indicating that the distance measure also reliably reflects how individual's moral decisions follows group consensus. Importantly, both indices of the group consensus moral decision were not related to the individual percentage of making utilitarian decisions (moral similarity (r(104) = .016, p = .870); moral distance (r(104) = -.082, p = .410)).

Individual's subjective interoceptive awareness was measured with the Korean Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (K-MAIA (Gim et al., 2016)), a self-report instrument assessing multiple dimensions of interoception. The bivariate relationships between the K-MAIA score and both the moral similarity and moral distance were assessed. The moral similarity scores were positively correlated with the K-MAIA scores (r(74) = .237, p = .042; Fig 2A), and the moral distance measures were negatively correlated with the K-MAIA scores (r(74) = -.240, p = .039; Fig 2B). Importantly, the K-MAIA score did not correlate with the ratio of utilitarian choices across all scenarios (r(74) = -.178, p = .129). The bivariate relationship between K-MAIA score and moral similarity and moral distance for high-and low-level group consensus scenarios were assessed separately. The K-MAIA score was positively correlated with moral similarity (r -.369, p = .001; Fig 2C) and negatively with moral distance (r = -.354, p = .002; Fig 2D) in low consensus scenarios, but the bivariate relationships were not significant in high consensus scenarios (moral distance: r = .055, p = .640; moral similarity: r = -.074, p = .530). Our next question was whether the finding of Study 1 can be replicated using a more objective measure of interoception to predict individuals' moral decisions. To this end, we used the heartbeat detection task, which has been widely used to assess interoceptive accuracy (Schandry, 1981) . The moral similarity and the moral distance measures were calculated identically.

Consistent with the results of Study 1, individual's interoceptive accuracy score was positively correlated with moral similarity (r(30) = .422, p = .020; Fig 3A), and negatively correlated with moral distance (r(30) = -.436, p = .016; Fig 3B). Again, individual's utilitarian choice ratio was not related to interoceptive accuracy (r(30) = -.039, p = .839). Moreover, the same correlations were significant in personal dilemma scenarios (moral distance: r = -.477, p = .009, Figure 3D;
moral similarity: r = .456, p = .013, Figure 3C), but not in impersonal scenarios (moral distance: r = -.345, p = .062; moral similarity: r = .223, p = .235).

div.head: Fig. 3. Moral intuition to group consensus moral decision is related to interoceptive sensitivity measured by the heartbeat counting task (Study 2). (A)
div.p: The moral intuition index measured as the moral similarity to the group consensus decision was positively correlated to individuals' interoceptive accuracy measured by the heartbeat counting task level (r = .422, p = .020), indicating that the more similar one's moral decisions were to the group consensus decision, the more accurate the individual's interoceptive performance was in the heartbeat detection task. (B) The moral intuition measured as the distance from group consensus was negatively correlated with interoceptive accuracy measured by the heartbeat counting task, indicating that the closer one's decision was to the group consensus decision, the more accurate the individual's interoceptive performance was in the heartbeat counting task. (r = -.436, p = .016) (C) The moral similarity in personal dilemmas was positively correlated with interoceptive accuracy (r = .457, p = .011). (D)
The moral distance in personal dilemmas was negatively correlated with interoceptive accuracy (r = -.477, p = .008).

div.head: Resting state functional connectivity between anterior insula and precuneus is related to moral decision toward group consensus
div.p: Many recent studies have shown that task-independent neural measures such as resting-state fMRI can provide reliable and temporally stable measures of individual differences and predict specific behaviors (Horien et al., 2019;W. H. Jung & Kim, 2020). Based on these findings, we expected that people with higher interoceptive abilities would show stronger functional connections from anterior insula, a hub region in interoceptive processing (Kleckner et al., 2017;Seth, 2013), with regions included in the default mode network (DMN) such as medial prefrontal cortex and precuneus, which are known to be involved in self-related processes (Ochsner et al., 2005;Qin & Northoff, 2011) and internally focused cognition as well as mental simulation (Spreng et al., 2010), and moral judgment (Greene et al., 2001). To test this hypothesis, we tested whether resting-state functional connectivity of the insula (Critchley et al., 2004;Kleckner et al., 2017) can be used to predict individual differences in moral decision towards group consensus, by using resting state fMRI data previously obtained from the same participants in Study 1 for a different study with a larger database. We found that the strength in the functional connectivity between the insula and the precuneus (MNI: x = 4, y = -52, z = 30, p-FDR = .017 was negatively correlated with the moral distance measure (Fig 4A), that is, the stronger the connectivity is INTEROCEPTION AND MORAL INTUITION between the right insula and precuneus, the closer one's moral decision is to the group consensus.

This connectivity strength was positively correlated with the moral similarity to group decision (r = .442, p < .001) but was not related to the ratio of utilitarian choices (r = .034, p = .776). No significant cluster was found with individual moral similarity and utilitarian choice ratio used as predictor variables. No significant relationship was found between the connectivity strength and age, gender, and K-MAIA scores.

To test whether other anatomical regions included in the DMN are also related to the individual tendency making moral decisions in line with the group consensus, we extracted the effect of moral distance on the connectivity from anterior insula from the 4 anatomical regions of the DMN (the precuneus, bilateral TPJ, and MPFC), after controlling for age and gender as covariates. We found that the effect was only significant in the precuneus cluster (t(70) = -1.94, p = .027, one-sided), but not in other regions (Fig 4B). Empathic tendencies are reported to be related to being aware of social situational context, and to being socially anxious (Pittelkow et al., 2021), suggesting a relationship between empathy and being affected by behaviors of others. To explore the role of interoception in this relation, we conducted a mediation analysis. Moral distance from group consensus displayed significant direct associations with interoceptive accuracy (r(30) = -.436, p = .016) and subjective report of affective empathy (TEQ score, r(30) = -.475, p = .008). However, there were no direct effects of interoceptive accuracy on affective empathy (r(30) = .239, p = .203). We explored whether the moral intuition mediates the effect of interoceptive accuracy on the subjective report of empathy.
A mediation analysis revealed that the moral distance from group consensus significantly mediated the effect of interoceptive accuracy on subjective report of affective empathy (Table 1).

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: This study explored the potential link between interoception and an individual's inclination to align their moral decisions with group consensus, the commonly accepted moral choice. As predicted, the results revealed a positive correlation between interoceptive awareness and accuracy and the extent to which individuals made moral decisions in line with group consensus across various scenarios. Additionally, this inclination was positively associated with functional connectivity between the insula and the precuneus during resting states. These findings underscore the significance of interoception as a potential biological foundation for constructing accurate internal models of social expectations and fostering moral intuition aligned with group consensus-an efficient strategy for minimizing metabolic costs related to bodily maintenance.

Humans both influence and are influenced by social surroundings, and there is empirical evidence from various domains supporting the idea that our brains track the consensus of those around us across a wide range of contexts, like public health campaigns (Falk et al., 2015), crowdfunding projects (Genevsky et al., 2017), social judgments like facial preference (H. Kim et al., 2007) and facial trustworthiness (Engell et al., 2007). This study extends the existing body of empirical evidence into moral decision-making, bridging the gap between empirical findings and theoretical explanations of consensus-based decision-making. It empirically establishes the existence of group consensus in moral preferences, even in situations lacking universally "right"

answer. Notably, this study elucidates that individuals typically make moral choices that align with the prevailing group consensus, and it highlights the role of interoceptive sensitivity in shaping these individual differences. Individuals develop internal models reflecting societal norms and others' expectations in their social milieu (Constant et al., 2019;Theriault et al., 2021).

These internal models form one's "sense of should" (Theriault et al., 2021) compelling us to conform our behavior to the cultural or social norms (Constant et al., 2019;Ramstead et al., 2016). Adhering to our sense of should and conforming to others' expectations contribute to maintaining a more predictable social environment, serving as a means of conserving metabolic efficiency as we navigate the complexities of social life and adapt to them (Theriault et al., 2021).

Interoceptive signals convey essential information about an organism's internal state, which is critical for maintaining homeostasis (Craig, 2002), playing a pivotal role in enabling an organism to adapt effectively to a dynamic environment by minimizing discrepancies between predicted and actual bodily states (Barrett & Simmons, 2015;Seth, 2013). The present study supports these theoretical frameworks by demonstrating that the inclination to make moral decisions aligned with group consensus is associated with interoceptive sensitivity. Both subjective and objective measures of interoceptive sensitivity correlate with individuals' tendency to align their moral decisions with group consensus. Interoceptive accuracy reflects one's ability to attend to interoceptive sensory signals and determine their weight in shaping their perception during heartbeat counting task (Ainley et al., 2016). This optimization enables individuals to generate prediction errors and effectively update their generative model. Consequently, individuals with higher interoceptive accuracy can more precisely identify and allocate the appropriate weight to relevant sources of information when interpreting physiological responses in diverse social contexts (Ainley et al., 2016). This precision leads to more accurate prediction errors, which, in turn, update their internal model of the social environment.

It is important to note that interoceptive sensitivity does not correlate with the consistency of an individual's utilitarian or deontological decision-making, consistent with recent research (Tamura et al., 2022). Previous studies have reported associations between certain neural structures, particularly the vmPFC, a critical component of the interoceptive neural circuitry, and the ratio of utilitarian or deontological decision choices. However, since individuals typically anticipate that deontological choices in moral dilemmas are favorably regarded by others, the link between vmPFC lesions and an increased inclination toward utilitarian decisions might be attributed to the acquired challenge of accurately gauging societal expectations in specific moral situations. Supporting this view, behavioral impairment resulting from vmPFC lesions, along with heightened vmPFC activity, were primarily evident in personal moral scenarios where deontological choices (e.g., prioritizing the avoidance of physical harm to a minority) tend to align with the expectations of the broader population (Lee et al., 2014(Lee et al., , 2018. To avoid this confounding effect, our study carefully selected moral scenarios to eliminate potential correlations between group consensus and utilitarian (or deontological) decisions, shedding light on the need for further research to elucidate the precise role of the vmPFC in moral dilemma.

Our data also revealed an indirect relationship between interoceptive accuracy and self-reported empathic ability, mediated by moral alignment with group consensus. Higher interoceptive accuracy was linked to a shorter moral distance from group consensus, which, in turn, was associated with higher self-reported affective empathy. However, interoceptive accuracy and self-reported affective empathic ability were not directly related in our sample. Previous research has suggested a connection between interoceptive abilities and empathy, albeit with differing results (Ainley et al., 2015;Grynberg & Pollatos, 2015;Stoica & Depue, 2020), especially when employing self-reported empathy assessment. One potential explanation is that having an intuition aligned with group consensus may be a prerequisite for experiencing an appropriate affective response to others' situations, which, in turn, may lay the foundation for selfassessments of empathy toward others.

We explored whether the functional connectivity of the anterior insula, crucial for interoceptive signal processing (Kleckner et al., 2017;Seth, 2013), are associated with individuals' inclination to make moral decisions aligned with group consensus. Our predefined regions of interest included the precuneus (or the posterior cingulate cortex) and the mPFC, both major components of the DMN (Babo-Rebelo et al., 2016;Buckner et al., 2008) implicated in self-related processing (Buckner et al., 2008;Qin & Northoff, 2011) and monitoring of bodily signals (Thayer et al., 2012). Our data revealed that the intrinsic functional connectivity between the right dorsal anterior insula and the precuneus was inversely related to the extent to which an individual's moral decisions deviated from the general consensus.

The insular cortex encodes and represents interoceptive information (Craig, 2002;Gu et al., 2013), responds to both external and internal information sources (Menon & Uddin, 2010), and mediates the impact of interoceptive signals on behaviors (Ainley et al., 2016), potentially playing a pivotal role in social and moral decision-making (Baumgartner et al., 2013; J. Kim & Kim, 2021). The precuneus serves various complex cognitive functions, including autobiographical memory retrieval, self-related information processing, and the integration of environmental perception-related information (Lou et al., 2004;Lyu et al., 2021), and is a major hub within the DMN (Utevsky et al., 2014). Thus, the stronger connectivity between the right anterior insula and the precuneus may signify a stable, task-independent individual trait marked by heightened sensitivity to interoceptive information during rest. This trait could serve as a crucial biological foundation for moral intuition enabling individuals to accurately develop and reference internal models reflecting the expectations of others in complex social environments.
In conclusion, this study empirically supports the significant role of interoception in forming and executing intuitive moral decisions that are aligned with group consensus. While our findings

div.head: OPEN PRACTICES STATEMENT
div.p: The studies reported in this article were not preregistered. The data and code for Study 1 and Study 2 are publicly accessible at https://osf.io/432nf/?view_only=f0b4cc345c664493addfec8aea1486d9. Requests can be made for Korean translated version of scenarios used in this study to the corresponding author.

figure.figDesc: implemented in SPSS PROCESS macros. The model included the independent variable of interoceptive accuracy, the outcome variable of empathy measured with TEQ, and the mediating variable of the moral distance from group consensus.Resting-state fMRI data acquisition and preprocessingMRI data were acquired with a Siemens Magnetom Prisma 3T scanner equipped with a 64channel head coil. Whole brain functional images during rest were acquired with the following parameters: TR= 1.35 sec, TE = 0.03 sec, slice thickness = 3 mm, imaging matrix = 80 x 80 mm, field of view = 240 mm, voxel size = 3 x 3 x 3 mm, number of slices = 46, flip angle = 90º. 304 volumes of functional images were acquired for each participant and preprocessed following the default preprocessing pipeline in CONN Toolbox (20b) and SPM12. Images were first realigned and corrected for slice timing. Structural images were normalized to a Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) template with affine registration, followed by nonlinear transformation. Scans with excessive head motion-related artifacts were detected and discarded using the 'intermediate' threshold (i.e., global Bold signal changes > 5 standard deviation and framewise displacement > 0.9 mm). The normalization parameters determined for the structural volume were applied to the functional images. Images were then smoothed with an 8 mm Gaussian kernel at FWHM (Full width at half-maximum). The resulting pre-processed resting-state fMRI data underwent additional post-processing steps to reduce the artifact related to head motion and non-neuronal physiological variations. Regression of the (1) 5 principal components and temporal derivatives from the white matter and cerebrospinal fluid time series using anatomical component-based noise correction procedure (aCompCor)(Behzadi et al., 2007), (2) 12 realignment parameters, and (3) effect of condition (rest) and temporal band-pass filtering (0.008-0.09Hz) were

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Evidence for quantifiable moral intuition to group consensus based on decisions in moral dilemma scenarios. (A) The group-level moral consensus decision was defined as the decision the majority of the participants chose for each scenario. (B)

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Moral intuition to group consensus moral decision is related to the individuals' self-reported interoceptive awareness (Study 1). (A) Moral similarity to group consensus decision was calculated as the ratio of individual's decisions that match the group consensus moral decision, and this measure was positively correlated with the individuals' self-reported interoceptive awareness measured with K-MAIA. (B) Moral distance from group consensus decision was calculated as the mean of the Euclidean distance between an individual's moral decision and the mean utilitarian choice ratio for each scenario, and this measure was negatively correlated with the individuals' selfreported interoceptive awareness. (C) Moral similarity to group consensus in low consensus scenarios was positively correlated with interoceptive awareness. (D) Moral distance from group consensus in low consensus scenarios were negatively correlated with interoceptive awareness.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Resting-state fMRI connectivity pattern related to individuals' moral distance from group consensus decisions (Study 1). (A) Intrinsic functional connectivity between anterior insula and precuneus are negatively related to moral distance from group consensus. The precuneus showed a significant association between the moral distance from group consensus decisions and the functional connectivity with the anterior insula seed (p-FDR < .05, cluster-level corrected). (B) The effect of moral distance on the connectivity between anterior insula and 4 landmark regions of the DMN. Error bar indicates 95% CI. Moral distance from group consensus mediates the effect of interoceptive accuracy on selfreported empathy

suggest that interoceptive inference contributes to the development and utilization of moral intuition rooted in group preferences, future research should delve deeper into the precise mechanisms and roles of interoceptive inference in these processes. While resting-state functional connectivity reveals an individual's stable traits over time, and is a valuable tool for understanding less context-dependent individual characteristics and predicting behaviors, taskrelated fMRI studies may offer a more precise understanding of the mechanisms
